greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of permutations tau of {1,...,n} such that k^2 + tau(k)^2 is prime for every k = 1,...,n.
comment: Conjecture 1: The number a(n) is always a square, and a(n) = 0 only for n = 7.
Conjecture 2: For any positive integer n, there is a permutation tau of {1,...,n} such that k^2 + k*tau(k) + tau(k)^2 is prime for every k = 1,...,n.
See also A321597 and A321611 for similar conjectures.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Primes arising from permutations (II), Question 315341 on Mathoverflow, Nov. 14, 2018.
Zhi-Wei Sun, A mysterious connection between primes and squares, Question 315351 on Mathoverflow, Nov. 15, 2018.
example: a(3) = 1, and (1,3,2) is a permutation of {1,2,3} with 1^2 + 1^2 = 2, 2^2 + 3^2 = 13 and 3^2 + 2^2 all prime.
program: (PARI) a(n) = matpermanent(matrix(n, n, i, j, ispseudoprime(i^2 + j^2))); \\ _Jinyuan Wang_, Jun 13 2020
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Nov 14 2018
